title: Checkpoint: Quarter 4 (Probability + Advanced Expressions & Functions)
description: Assessment covering Units 7-8: probability, compound events, evaluating expressions, equation word problems, function input/output, and patterns.

remediationStrategy.description: Students scoring below threshold receive focused reteaching on their weakest Quarter 4 skills. Remediation prioritizes conceptual gaps in probability reasoning and algebraic fluency.

clusters.reteachFocus: P(event) = favorable/total, complementary probability P(not A) = 1 − P(A), expressing probability as fractions/decimals/percents, impossible (0) vs. certain (1)
Sample space listing and tree diagrams, counting principle (multiply branches), P(A and B) for independent events, organized outcome tables for two-event experiments
Substitution with negative values (watch sign errors), order of operations with exponents, evaluating rational expressions, simplifying before substituting
Defining variables from context, translating 'more than / less than / times as many' into algebra, setting up and solving multi-step equations, verifying answers in the original context
Using a rule to compute outputs from inputs, working backwards from output to find input (inverse operations), completing function tables, recognizing linear function rules from tables
Identifying arithmetic sequences (constant difference), writing explicit rules (start + rate × step), finding the nth term, working backwards from a term value to find n

assessmentProblems.question: A bag contains 5 red marbles, 3 blue marbles, and 2 green marbles. You draw one marble at random. What is the probability of drawing a blue marble? Express your answer as a fraction.

A standard deck has 52 cards. You draw one card at random. What is the probability of drawing a card that is NOT a face card (not a Jack, Queen, or King)? Express your answer as a fraction in simplest form.
assessmentProblems.answer: Face cards: 4 Jacks + 4 Queens + 4 Kings = 12. Non-face cards: 52 − 12 = 40. P(not face) = 40/52 = 10/13.

assessmentProblems.question: You flip a fair coin and roll a standard 6-sided die. How many total outcomes are possible? What is the probability of getting heads AND a number greater than 4?
assessmentProblems.answer: Total outcomes = 2 × 6 = 12. Favorable: heads AND (5 or 6) = 1 × 2 = 2 outcomes. P = 2/12 = 1/6.

assessmentProblems.question: A spinner has 4 equal sections labeled 1, 2, 3, and 4. You spin it twice. What is the probability that the sum of the two spins is exactly 5? List all favorable outcomes.
Evaluate the expression 3x² − 2x + 7 when x = 4. Show each step.
Evaluate the expression (a² − b²) ÷ (a + b) when a = 9 and b = 5. Show your work.
assessmentProblems.answer: (9² − 5²) ÷ (9 + 5) = (81 − 25) ÷ 14 = 56 ÷ 14 = 4. (Note: a² − b² = (a+b)(a−b), so this simplifies to a − b = 9 − 5 = 4.)

assessmentProblems.question: Maria has $45 and saves $8 each week. Her brother has $69 and spends $4 each week. After how many weeks will they have the same amount of money? How much will each person have?
assessmentProblems.answer: Maria: 45 + 8w. Brother: 69 − 4w. Set equal: 45 + 8w = 69 − 4w. 12w = 24. w = 2 weeks. Amount: 45 + 8(2) = $61 each. Check: 69 − 4(2) = 69 − 8 = $61 ✓

assessmentProblems.question: A rectangular garden has a perimeter of 56 meters. The length is 4 meters more than twice the width. Find the length and width of the garden.
A function rule is y = 2x + 3. Find the output for each input: x = −2, x = 0, x = 1, and x = 5.
A machine uses the rule: output = 3(input) − 7. If the output is 20, what was the input? Show your work.
Look at the sequence: 4, 11, 18, 25, 32, … What is the pattern rule? What is the 10th term?
assessmentProblems.answer: Each term increases by 7. Rule: term = 7n − 3 (where n is the term number). Check: 7(1) − 3 = 4 ✓, 7(2) − 3 = 11 ✓. 10th term: 7(10) − 3 = 67.

assessmentProblems.question: A tile pattern grows: Figure 1 has 5 tiles, Figure 2 has 9 tiles, Figure 3 has 13 tiles, Figure 4 has 17 tiles. (a) How many tiles will Figure 7 have? (b) Which figure number will have exactly 41 tiles?
assessmentProblems.answer: (a) Pattern increases by 4 each figure. Rule: tiles = 4n + 1. Figure 7: 4(7) + 1 = 29 tiles. Check: 4(1)+1=5 ✓, 4(2)+1=9 ✓. (b) 4n + 1 = 41. 4n = 40. n = 10. Figure 10 has 41 tiles.
